posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Pope Francis, Dandrieu notes, seems intent on severing the bond between Catholicism and European civilization. The late Benedict XVI defended Catholicism's European roots, but also associated it with certain messianism, as on World Day of Migrants in 2011, when he claimed that migration is “the prefiguration of an undivided City of God.” In his encyclical Caritas in veritate, as Dandrieu reminds us, he expressed one of the basic globalist tenets: the belief in the necessity of global institutions that would attend to the common good of all mankind and implement its unity.

Looking for the sources of this “contamination” of true Catholic universalism by globalism, Dandrieu points to personalism. This intellectual current has detached Catholicism from the notion of the common good, shifting the focus to the individual. While the ideas of Jacques Maritain and his disciples sought to criticize liberalism, they inadvertently led to its triumph within the church. In a personalist vein, John XXIII defined the common good as “safeguarding the rights and duties of the human person,” thus disregarding its inherently communal dimension, central to St. Thomas’s thought and to the whole classical Catholic tradition. Absent an anchor in the common good, personalism has degenerated into subjectivism, providing the intellectual and moral conditions for the utopian pipe dream of a united humanity.

>The cog was a boat design which is believed to have evolved from (or at least have been influenced by) the longship and was in wide use by the 12th century. It too used the clinker method of construction. Ships began to be built with straight stem posts and the rudder was fixed to the stern post which made a boat easier to steer. To make ships faster, more masts and sails were fitted.

The Hanseatic League was an alliance of trading guilds that established and maintained a trade monopoly over the Baltic Sea and to a certain extent the North Sea in the Late Middle Ages, starting in the 13th century. Protection for the league was given in England in 1157. Warehouses belonging to the league were set up in eight English ports and one Scottish port. By the 16th century the league imploded and there was a rise of Dutch and English merchants.

In the 14th and 15th centuries, seamen's guilds were formed in Bristol, King's Lynn, Grimsby, Hull, York and Newcastle.

Age of Exploration
From the early 15th century, continuing into the 17th century, English ships travelled around the world searching for new trading partners and establishing new trading routes. In the process new peoples were encountered and lands were mapped that were previously unknown to the English. Bristol ships were venturing into the Atlantic Ocean in 1480/1 and may have reached Newfoundland.
>During the 17th century ship experienced significant change. During the early part of the 17th century, English shipbuilders developed sturdy, well masted and defensible ships, that because of the way they were rigged, required a significant crew to man.

>>14550599
England's first known navy was established by Alfred the Great which, despite inflicting a significant defeat on the Vikings in the Wantsum Channel, Kent, fell into disuse. It was revived by Athelstan and had 400 ships in 937. When the Norman invasion was imminent, King Harold had trusted his navy to prevent William the Conqueror's fleet from crossing the Channel. However, not long before the invasion, the fleet was damaged in a storm, driven into harbour and the Normans were able to cross unopposed.

The Norman kings created a naval force in 1155, or adapted a force that already existed, with ships provided by the Cinque Ports. The English Navy began to develop during the 12th and 13th centuries, King John having a fleet of 500 sails. In the mid 14th century Edward III's navy had 712 ships. There then followed a period of decline.

Again, the base of English Naval Supremacy was formed in the viking age, the added Carracks in the 15th century does not detract from the original roots of their naval power

I'm Jewish, and I have a very large Jewish family with both very religious and very secular members.

For my religious family members, the most common opinion on him is "he probably didn't exist, but if he did, he was just a mortal preacher." They don't have any strong opinion on what he preached, neither demonizing nor praising.

My less religious family is willing to admit that Jesus existed, but they also see him as merely a wise mortal leader, without any prophetic abilty orany other particular exceptionalism. They think his teachings are mostly bood, but they do it in that way that secular liberals tend to like Jesus.

My personal opinions tend to allign similar to my less religious family, but I try hard not to fall into the common trap that liberals fall into conflating Jesus into some sort of hippie. I think he was a mortal man with a mortal follower whose teachings touched the hearts of so many of his compatriots, and I'm glad that others find meaning in his message even if I do not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14546291
The most likely theory is that they lived between Pripet marshes and Carpathians(Podolia etc.). Archaeology hints towards south of this range, but the marshes were poorly surveyed and given Chernobyl and the current war it won't change anytime soon, not to mention that the local microclimate makes preservation of artifacts there harder, so we may be dealing with discovery bias. The area in abstract makes sense because:
1. Assuming they didn't cross mountain ranges as they've migrated, the distance they could cover between the collapse of the hunnic empire and their first mentions by byzantines is proportional with the distance between it and the earliest finds of slavic like pottery in the Czech Republic.
2. The area is poorly known by the Romans, meaning that if you're looking for some kind of proto-slavs that should be somewhere but are never mentioned that is a good place to look for.
3. They must have had some contact with some of the steppe Iranians like Sarmatians or Scythians which would make sense there, but wouldn't make sense closer to the Baltic.
4. The "forest Scythians" Herodotus mentions that sometimes are associated with slavs would have to live exactly there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14543404
Despite the huge size of the complex most residents had no idea what was going on. In many ways they had it better than a lot of Poles in other parts of Poland. The huge number of SS personnel and other German settlers required servants and many residents found employment and protection that way. My grandmother was a teenage girl during the war and she became a maid for a family of German settlers who actually treated her well, giving her all sorts of luxury items for her service. On the flipside a portion of the population was expelled to make space for the camp and some residents became more aware or less complicit than others and were smuggling medicine and food inside the camp or helping forced laborers escape.
Generally speaking the public was unaware of what was going on inside the camp until the later stages of the war. From 1942 to 1944 a lot of escapees wrote reports that eventually made their way to the Home Army, then the Polish government in exile, then the Allied governments and finally the press. This increased awareness eventually led Jewish communities in the US and Britain to advocate for bombing campaigns against the camp's railway infrastructure but the only raid that actually took place was against IG Farben works at the Monowitz subcamp

>>14543443
Auschwitz II originally started off as a POW camp, but it's purpose quickly changed
It wasn't a pure extermination camp in a sense that everyone who ended up at Birkenau would be gassed, but rather it served as both a giant distribution centre for the Reich's slave labor system as well as an extermination place for those who were deemed too useless to be a slave laborer. Many people (mainly Poles) were in Birkenau only for transit purposes. Out of those who remained not all of them were killed outright as the Auschwitz complex had its own labor requirements. Inmates were used to expand the camp, guard each other, sort through people's personal belongings or for work in various subcamps. So in this sense it wasn't a pure extermination camp, but industrial killing was without a shadow of a doubt one of Birkenau's functions

>>14551050
Wooden doors can be made gas tight if constructed sturdily enough, and with a sealing material between the slats, which these doors were. The preassure differences between the inside of the room and the outside of the room would have been equal; the only gas transfer the doors would have needed to counter was from diffusion. They did not need to be pressure-sealed hatches like what you see on submarines, for example.

Keep in mind also that poison gas killes based on its concentration. Even the presence of small leaks would not have hampered operation of the gas chamber. Consider how with carbon monoxide poisoning, some people in the building can die while others in a nearby room remain unharmed.

You don't seem to realize how far behind the rest of the world was. In the 15th century and early 16th century Italian mathematicians solved a flurry of centuries old problems that stumped the Greeks and the Indian and Muslim world, for example they dabbled in cubic equations but it wasn't until Ferro and Tartaglia that a complete solution was found. There were also technical innovations, if China was "wild", Europe during the late middle ages and renaissance must have been a "heckin' beast fr fr", for example France had water powered saw mills in the 14th century, Flemish weavers invented new vertical looms that tripled productivity, Flemish forges developed methods of carburizing or decarburizing iron and imported low impurity ore from far off places to produce high quality steel. When Europe reached India and China they only had a handful of innovations the Europeans did not, usually related to things Europe did not have like cotton or lacquer.

Further you vastly overinflate the significance of colonialism. The industrial revolution was in full swing in Britain at the turn of the 18th century with Isaac Newton and the first economically productive steam engines pumping water out of mines, before this point most goods from the colonies were spices and precious metals, the former is a luxury, the latter lost much of its value due to inflation. Aztec gold and silver was in fact spent on an invasion of England, though I would not actually consider this important in the larger scale of things. The overwhelming majority of economic activity and technological development was taking place in Europe and continued to be even in the industrial revolution when cotton and others goods from the colonies had a significant impact, but by this time the scientific underpinnings of the industrial revolution were already there.

If you stop looking at it in terms of truisms and flesh out your analysis a little, your narrative is highly distorted.

The following day she was confused, hallucinating, incontinent of urine and quite unable to eat or drink. For the next two days she was intermittently hallucinating and screaming with terror until she collapsed and had a cardiac arrest. Although she was resuscitated in the ambulance whilst being carried to intensive care, she died two days later, on 24th of August 1981, without recovering consciousness.

The Stonehenge Free Festival was a British free festival from 1974 to 1984 held at the prehistoric monument Stonehenge in England during the month of June, and culminating with the summer solstice on or near 21 June. It emerged as the major free festival in the calendar after the violent suppression of the Windsor Free Festival in August 1974, with Wally Hope providing the impetus for its founding, and was itself violently suppressed in 1985 in the Battle of the Beanfield, with no free festival held at Stonehenge since although people have been allowed to gather at the stones again for the solstice since 1999.

By the 1980s, the festival had grown to be a major event, attracting up to 30,000 people in 1984. The festival attendees were branded as hippies by the British press. This, along with the open drug use and sale, contributed to the increase in restrictions on access to Stonehenge, and fences were erected around the stones in 1977. The same year, police resurrected a moribund law against driving over grassland in order to levy fines against festival goers in motorised transport. By 1984 police-festival relations were relaxed with only a nominal police presence required. Tabernacle of G-D being crushed since 1985.

https://www.andyworthington.co.uk/2009/06/20/its-25-years-since-the-last-stonehenge-free-festival

>>14551100
I'll give you the ultra-condensed version. Huxley wrote a good book on it, which you should read if you're more interested in it.

All or at least most religions (sometimes called inspired religions) all have their origins from the same ultimate source, often called the Perennial Truth. The Perennial Truth has been misinterpreted by every single human culture, its pure light tinted by the lens of their culture and biases; there is no 100% true religion.

While some might say that the solution is to mix all of the Inspired religions together, such a venture is doomed to fail. Such a creation would also be shaped by the biases of the day, and would be just one more imperfect copy of the Perennial Truth.

The best course of action, then, is to stick to one form of worship - the religion that best suits your individual biases (often but not always the religion you were born in) - and to 'refine' your worship by the study of other religions.

By taking a comparative approach to the understanding of religion, by trying to find and undstand the similarities and the differences that inspired religions share, you begin to understand more of your own personal worship, and in this way can apprach a little bit closer to the Perennial Truth.

The Catholic Church *is* the original Church.

The role of apostolic succession in preserving true doctrine is stated by Paul: To ensure that the apostles’ teachings would be passed down, Paul told Timothy:
>“[W]hat you have heard from me before many witnesses entrust to faithful men who will be able to teach others also” (2 Tm 2:2).

In this passage Paul refers to the first three generations of apostolic succession—his own generation, Timothy’s generation, and the generation Timothy will teach.

By the end of the second century, apostolic succession was understood as the sure indicator of orthodoxy. St Irenaeus of Lyons, writing against the Gnostics around the year 180:
>Since, however, it would be very tedious, in such a volume as this, to reckon up the successions of all the Churches, we do put to confusion all those who... whether by an evil self-pleasing, by vainglory, or by blindness and perverse opinion, assemble in unauthorized meetings; [we do this, I say,] by indicating that tradition derived from the apostles, of the very great, the very ancient, and universally known Church founded and organized AT ROME by the two most glorious apostles, Peter and Paul; as also [by pointing out] the faith preached to men, which comes down to our time by means of the successions of the bishops.

>For it is A MATTER OF NECESSITY that EVERY CHURCH SHOULD AGREE WITH THIS CHURCH [i.e. Rome], on account of its preeminent authority.
-St Irenaeus, Against Heresies 3.3.2, 180 AD (emphasis added)

Btw, both the Orthodox and the Catholics venerate Irenaeus as a saint.

All language is subject to interpretation and dispute. This is the nature of the human condition.

See: "Fetch Some Soupmeat"
https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/72828643.pdf

Thus, "Catholicism is true" would have resulted in endless disputes about its meaning, e.g., *which* Catholicism is true?

Now, the way Christ addressed this problem was investing teaching authority in His Church. At the same time, He has given humans free will and free intellects, so there is always room for disputes.

>Easy. No wars. No denomination splits.
The only way to do away with such things would be to do away with the human intellect as we currently experience it (i.e., free, and capable of skepticism), as well as free will.

Which is to say, God could have made a world of robots instead of the world we currently live in, of human beings.

As Thomas More said:
>God made the angels to show Him splendor, as He made animals for innocence and plants for their simplicity.
>But Man He made to serve Him wittily, in the tangle of his mind.

Or, as a more recent commentator puts it:

God created us out of love and He gave us the ability to freely love in return.

Love that is not freely given is not true love. God's love for us is true.

He gives us free will so we can have the freedom to choose to truly love Him back (or not).

posts.com: How exactly is transubstantiation supposed to work if you’re a nominalist? Does being Catholic or Lutheran just kind of force to to be believe in universals?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14550813
It requires a deep dive to address this question.

This article does so, and seems to conclude that a nominalist *could* hold to transubstantiation, with that conclusion resting, among other things, on the grounds that Ockham believed in transubstantiation:

William J. Courtenay, "Cranmer as a Nominalist: Sed contra" (Harvard Theo. Rev., vol. 57, no. 4) (Oct 1964), pp. 367-380.
Link: https://www.jstor.org/stable/1508569

The article is free on jstor, you just have to register for a free account.

One observation. The article doesn't appear to address the fact that the Council of Trent does not appear to require belief in all the particulars of St. Thomas's theory of transubstantiation (Thomas didn't invent the word; it was used by the Church to characterize the Eucharistic change before Aquinas was born).

In sum, the Church at Trent required that Catholics believe that "a change is brought about of the whole substance of the bread into the substance of the body of Christ," but it pointedly avoiding speaking of "accidents," from which it can be inferred that Trent did not impose the Aristotelian theory of substance and accidents, or Aristotelian metaphysics, as such, but rather, at least arguably, a more common-sense understanding of "substance".*

See: Chapter IV, Transubstantiation
https://www.ewtn.com/catholicism/library/thirteenth-session-of-the-council-of-trent-1479

*See, e.g., the discussion here:
https://www.ewtn.com/catholicism/library/on-transubstantiation-4810

Otoh, I have seen other theologians** who claim that by dint of using the word "substance," Trent necessarily *did* impose Aristotelianism. I personally think this is an open question, given the language of Trent.

**See:
https://www.praytellblog.com/index.php/2010/05/30/transubstantiation-and-aristotle-warning-heavy-philosophy/

Related article of interest:

Ed Feser, Transubstantiation and Hylemorphism
http://edwardfeser.blogspot.com/2019/10/transubstantiation-and-hylemorphism.html

In the 1804 election, Thomas Jefferson ran for a second term against Federalist candidate Charles Pinckney. Despite Federalist accusations that the Louisiana Purchase was unconstitutional (never mind their own doctrine of loose construction) and Jefferson had neglected military preparedness while war was raging in Europe, the president was enjoying huge popularity from the LP, a strong economy, and repeal of several unpopular Federalist policies. Alexander Hamilton's death in a duel with Aaron Burr that summer also removed the only strong leadership Federalists had. The results were never in doubt as Jefferson won reelection in an easy landslide, with 162 electoral votes to Pinckney's 14. Pinckney failed to carry his own state of South Carolina and indeed he carried only Delaware and Connecticut, as even Federalist bastion New England went for the president.

This was the first presidential election Ohio participated in, giving Jefferson its three electoral votes. The Buckeye State would soon establish a reputation as an electoral belweather; in 55 presidential elections since its admission as a state, it has voted for the winner all but a handful of times.

>Suppose a housekeeper says to a domestic: “fetch some soupmeat,” accompanying the act with giving some money to the latter; he will be unable to execute the order without interpretation, however easy and, consequently, rapid the performance of the process may be. Common sense and good faith tell the domestic, that the housekeeper’s meaning was this:
>1. He should go immediately, or as soon as his other occupations are finished; or, if he be directed to do so in the evening, that he should go the next day at the usual hour;
>2. that the money handed him by the housekeeper is intended to pay for the meat thus ordered, and not as a present to him;
>3. that he should buy such meat and of such parts of the animal, as, to his knowledge, has commonly been used in the house he stays at, for making soups;
>4. that he buy the best meat he can obtain, for a fair price;
>5. that he go to that butcher who usually provides the family, with whom the domestic resides, with meat, or to some convenient stall, and not to any unnecessarily distant place;
>6. that he return the rest of the money;
>7. that he bring home the meat in good faith, neither adding anything disagreeable nor injurious;
>8. that he fetch the meat for the use of the family and not for himself.

>Suppose, on the other hand, the housekeeper, afraid of being misunderstood, had mentioned these eight specifications, she would not have obtained her object, if it were to exclude all possibility of misunderstanding.
